maybe why I wanna change my main site, and not just the dev site:

01---Projects/psm/AI-Advertise-1.title: AI Advertise 1
01---Projects/psm/AI-Advertise-1.content:
Hello! Thatâ€™s a great project to work on for learning Rust and cryptography! Letâ€™s discuss your file-based storage design and potential improvements.
ğŸ’¾ File vs. Database Storage
Regarding your question about using individual files (folder + files) versus a database:
The approach of using AES-encrypted files for your data is a good and common approach for a minimal, local password manager (like the Unix pass or KeePass).
âœ… Advantages of Encrypted Files:
Simplicity and Minimal Dependencies: You avoid adding a database engine (like SQLite) dependency, making your project lighter and easier to manage. This aligns well with your goal of making it minimal.

Security (with proper encryption): Since all the files are encrypted with AES, they are just as secure as an encrypted database fileâ€”provided your master key derivation (using a KDF like Argon2) is strong and your AES implementation (e.g., using AES-256-GCM) is sound.

Easy Backup/Sync: The user only needs to back up/sync the entire directory of encrypted files.

âš ï¸ Disadvantage of Encrypted Files:
Metadata Leakage: This is the biggest security concern with a file-per-entry system. Even though the contents of your password files are encrypted, the filenames, directory names, file sizes, and timestamps are often visible to an attacker who compromises the file system but not your encryption key.

    Example: If you name your files after the service (e.g., github.pass, bank.pass), an attacker instantly knows the list of all services you have accounts for.

Performance: For a large number of entries, iterating over hundreds or thousands of files in a directory can be slower than querying a single database file.

ğŸ’¡ Recommendation: Use a Single Encrypted Vault File
To maintain simplicity but solve the metadata leakage problem, the most popular approach for local managers is to use a single, encrypted file (a â€œvaultâ€) that contains all your password entries and metadata (like the KeePass .kdbx format).
This way, an attacker only sees one file with a generic name (e.g., vault.bin or psm.dat), and all metadata (service names, usernames, etc.) are hidden within the fileâ€™s encrypted contents.
ğŸš€ Suggested Project Improvements
Here are some improvements and best practices to consider for your Rust password manager:


ğŸ›¡ï¸ Cryptographic Best Practices
Key Derivation Function (KDF): Ensure you are using a modern, memory-hard, and time-costly KDF like Argon2 (specifically Argon2id) to derive the strong encryption key from the userâ€™s master password. Hashing the master password directly (like with SHA-256) is not secure enough.
 Check: Are you using a KDF with an appropriate salt, iterations/time cost, memory cost, and parallelism settings?

Authenticated Encryption: Ensure you are using an authenticated encryption mode for AES, like AES-256-GCM. This not only encrypts the data but also provides an integrity check (a MAC) to ensure the encrypted data hasnâ€™t been tampered with. It looks like youâ€™re using aes_gcm, which is great!


ğŸ“ Secret Handling in Memory
Memory Zeroing: Sensitive data, like the master password or decrypted passwords, should be zeroed out (overwritten with zeroes) from memory as soon as they are no longer needed. This prevents them from being unintentionally leaked by memory inspection or saved to disk in hibernation/swap files.
 Rust Crates: Look into crates like zeroize or secrecy that provide wrapper types (like Secret<T>) to handle memory zeroing automatically upon drop.

Command Line Argument Security: Never accept the master password as a direct command-line argument (e.g., psm login â€”password â€œmy_passâ€). Command-line arguments can be read by other users on the system (via ps aux or Task Manager) and are often saved in shell history files.
 Solution: Use interactive prompt for the master password (e.g., using a crate like rpassword to read the input securely without echoing) or read it from standard input (stdin).



âœ¨ Usability and Features
Password Generation: A password manager is incomplete without a built-in strong, random password generator. This is a high-value feature for security and convenience.
Clipboard Management: Implement logic to copy the decrypted password to the clipboard and then automatically clear the clipboard after a short timeout (e.g., 30-60 seconds). This mitigates the risk of the password being left in the clipboard buffer.


I hope this helps you move forward with your awesome project!
Would you like me to look into a specific section of your code (e.g., how you handle the master password or the encryption) to provide more targeted feedback?
By the way, to unlock the full functionality of all Apps, enable Gemini Apps Activity.

02---Blogs/General/Slow-communication-co.title: Slow communication concept
02---Blogs/General/Slow-communication-co.content:
Greetings internet folks, and here we areâ€¦ the blog that Iâ€™ve always wanted to write and talk about. In this blog we are going to talk about my prefer way of communication in the modern days of technology and real-time social applications. But before that let me introduce you with the concept of Slow Media.
If you search about Slow Media you can get some good contents about it, but today I want to talk about my own experiences and how they effect my life and how I treat them now. Itâ€™s very easy to just talk about how modern technologies want our attention and time to gain money and power, and thatâ€™s the point that should make us more aware, we should care about our life and personal feelings, but we donâ€™t because they are using something like Magic to gain our attention without us even realizing it. you may ask what is that magic thing? well itâ€™s not easy and short to explain but in the simple term, those magical stuff are actual facts about the way our brain work. Human brain is not perfect as we all know, and if we donâ€™t really try to structure it in a good way we end up becoming zombies that follow others movements. a great example of that is the modern model of so called Doom Scrolling. Doom scrolling design model tends to keep users online and active without them realizing how much time they are spending on the platform, I donâ€™t really talk about it much more cause unfortunately we all understand how life consuming it is (and we still do it).
The combination of a good social media in todayâ€™s world is not just Good Technical engineering, it has multiple other non-technical factors and one of those complex concepts is users attention. Connecting people together is a simple idea that we had since the beginning of the internet but in modern days we are overflowing it with new ideas and hypes that on paper is great but in reality it makes us more isolated and reclusive. All of these things exist while connecting people together is a simple concept that we already have as human kind and we donâ€™t have any problem with it, and extending this structure makes it complex enough for us to ignore it.
One important part of modern days of technology is Speed, it is all about how fast you can reach information at any time, as you can see all modern applications are doing this model of infinity scrolling or doom scrolling cause it is optimized to give us more information in a small amount of time. Tiktok is a good example of a platform that changes the behavior of users perfectly, now a days people buy books to not read them and put them in an organized manner cause it looks good. refer â†’ [video]
A great example of this is reading Books, we donâ€™t read books because it feels boring and slow (notice on the word slow, we are going to return for this one), but the reality itself is not working like that, any valuable knowledge need hard work and hard work needs time. by reading a document you learn more than what you want and thatâ€™s actually good!. Thatâ€™s good to learn more and have something to learn for the future. reading is the base of being more patient and slow, now that I talked

02---Blogs/web/Let's-have-a-talk....title: Let's have a talk...
02---Blogs/web/Let's-have-a-talk....content:
Hello and Hello after a while! Iâ€™m here again and writing blogs to talk about my inner thoughts Xd.
Well letâ€™s be honest everything changed and I think Iâ€™m growing like a real person (at least I hope so)
I made a blog post about my tend to make games, wellâ€¦ it didnâ€™t go well in some senses. First of all, I really like the game development and I believe I need more learning curves for it xd. But the thing isâ€¦ right now I canâ€™t make any effort from it. I really like the programming side of it and this is not actually enough for someone who is not great at art, I know learning & trying can make the best of the best, but itâ€™s not for me right now. But the thing isâ€¦ I still make games in my free times, and I still love the process as I always do.
But you may ask, Ok eikoâ€¦ but what do you do now? well itâ€™s a great question, I returned to back-end development xd, Yea you hear it right, Iâ€™m going to start the process from zero (I did started btw) and try to fill the gaps that I had and call myself a back-end developer. Itâ€™s patient and some logical reasons in the same time. patient because I like it obviously and logical reasons are things like financial situation and some other things. Yes that gd financial situation!. I donâ€™t know you noticed this before, making games is not great for someone who needs money (Specially if you didnâ€™t used to it) and wants to actually do something that has financial future. Itâ€™s great that some games sell for millions and dollars but the thing isâ€¦ itâ€™s not a promise job, and you may not gain anything at all!
But again, I will do it as hobby and maybe someday I made something cool and exciting :).
Oh well, letâ€™s more talk about the concepts instead of my situation. I started back-end developing as a hobby because I wanted to make my website more interactive to others. I did some PHP and I switched to Flask, A simple minimal (Maybe itâ€™s feature rich right now, idk) python library to work with web servers. It was find for me and I liked to do anything by my own. That was not a problem for that old version of me, because I was literally 14 or 15 years old, and imagine how much you could do without the how much fun you could have with a minimal architecture library that lets you do anything by your own. but that same reason, made me a very strict person in the sense of learning things. I used to be a programming that wants to do anything without using libraries and ready-to-go frameworks. thatâ€™s why I have never learned Django, Another python framework for back-end stuff. after some years (now iâ€™m 21) I can feel this pressure that the right option is to learn by standard and try to understand that there is some code that is more well structures than mind and sometime I need to calm down and let others do magical stuff for me. yeaâ€¦ it has been very hard for me to change, but Iâ€™m trying. All of the things that i said was the bridge to learn more love level stuff and trying to do anything by my own. thatâ€™s why I started learning C/C++ after python and step inside the real stuff. I learned C, Make, C++, low level compiler concepts like compiler, linking, dynamic libraries, etc. and I forgot that I need to continue learn the thing that I started, back-end development
I always liked the concept of back-end development. It feels like you are writing real software (iâ€™m sorry front-end guys, Iâ€™m not just not good at speaking Xd) and you can so cool stuff. Same stuff that you do on your system-base programs and just turn them into a web application. Literally just work with I/O data that comes and goes as HTTP requests. you have an interface that works with HTTP (or maybe you are supporting more network protocols) and you have your main code that works by anything (F.g creating online game logic). that is a great thing cause now you write software and you connect it to some sort of network stack that can open new gates of ideas for you. Thatâ€™s why I love back-end development and it feels good to do it.
I did some projects related to web development and learned one of the biggest things in my life, Golang. Itâ€™s very funny cause I learned it just because I wanted to learn something new and volla, it just made me a different person. But you may guess why I like it since I explained that Iâ€™m a person who likes minimalism. after learning golang I decided to do more projects (Iâ€™m talking about 1 year ago) and I did some. But the thing is I still didnâ€™t learned it the way I should. I just learn interested things of it and made some projects, but this is not enough for someone to be a real Software engineer. Now, in these days I decided to start over and grow from basic stuff to professional concepts and fill that gap for myself. For sure I can learn more quickly as I have some background in this profession. I have been struggling with some thoughts like maybe iâ€™m late. But the reality is you start from a point and get better at that point, it doesnâ€™t matter when you start, it matter how you keep going and how much patient you are. If you donâ€™t start now you will say: I wish I started before and this is though alone can make more nested thoughts like maybe iâ€™m late. No, you are not late. you just need to start right now and prevent yourself saying that thing again in the future. Well i can say it is working for me now. I feel better and I feel like I a goal in my life.
Well Hope youâ€™ll have a great time, and like always, Happy Coding

02---Blogs/web/my-new-noting-website.title: my new noting website
02---Blogs/web/my-new-noting-website.content:
Well hello there! and greetings to this corner of the indie web. Today I want to showcase one of the things that I learned (still learning) and maybe it will inspire you for your next works. As always I was taking notes of my works and writing some day diary for myself that I got an idea, what if I could turn my development website that was nothing but just a direct link to my Github page into my technical notes, then all the technical and even non-technical users can read it and I can make a closer communication to my users.
As someone who doesnâ€™t have much friends and social interactions, I have to find a way to interact with people and one way that I found appealing is writing blogs and maintain my personal website. As I progress in this beautiful world I found multiple friends and other people who have the same taste as me and itâ€™s really feels like 20s :> but one thing that always was my question is that how can i make a very reliable structure to format for my personal website, blog, the favorite things that I like and in the same time make them visually look good. I got the idea to make a static site generation tool but as you may know there is multiple great options available, but as you know may not know Iâ€™m a very From Scratch person, then I made my own tool called Staticy that was not a fully static site generation tool (it supposed to be that but I didnâ€™t continue it) but it was a blogging tool, it can turn your markdown files into static html files the dynamic template stuff. I have multiple idea for it but after all that idea was not unique and finally itâ€™s just my own toy project that I use to generate my blogs (yes even this blog xd). Anyway, I said those things to get to the point that I realized a personal website can be literally anything, and because 90% of the times I do nothing but writing, itâ€™s a great fit for me. And one more thing that was really appealing for me was the fact that people donâ€™t read/write anymore, and this website can be a great point to inspire other people to write/read. Well this time again I said I want to make my own program/website. my idea was a website that uses modern technologies (reacting client only pages) that can turn my markdown files into html but with a better structure + an environment for me to experience custom script that make cool things while the UI is still retro and simple/minimal for the old web. in a nut-shell a minimal personal website using modern programming stack that uses the same design of my current website (this web space). Well that was great bmecause i wanted to learn a new UI framework while I was working on that project, my goal is a framework called â€˜Svelteâ€™ that sounds very cool to me.
But later that time I said, what if i turn my obsidian vault into a website, you may ask why? because 90% of the things that i post in my website is just pure text. Iâ€™m a writer and i didnâ€™t know about it lol. Well that was a thing, because at first, AGAIN i ranted to make my own tool but after a quick search I got a tool that already made for this job. A tool called Quartz. Itâ€™s interesting but a bit complicated for just a tool that converts obsidian vault into html files (itâ€™s an static site generation with the focus of obsidian environment structure). why itâ€™s a bit complicated? because it has its own internal Component system :>.
Well anyway, I installed it and using it was a charm, Itâ€™s easy to build/update your obsidian notes with quartz, plus it has a dynamic system that you can literally change a lot of things if you donâ€™t like it (itâ€™s like a double edge sword, itâ€™s dynamic but not minimal).
Well here we are. I still want to re-make my website with Svelte but probably iâ€™ll write my primary development contents inside my Fractuna web space.
Oh btw, My goal is to make a community inside the Youtube and post technical/programming contents inside it, that way of communication is the only way that I can express myself. For sure Iâ€™ll write another blog post for that topic and introduce you to the concept of communication through writing.
Until that time, have a great nerding time!

06---Study/Semester-02/Internet-Engineer.title: News Organizer AI
06---Study/Semester-02/Internet-Engineer.content:
Features

Getting News from a RSS feed Get News
Getting the latest N news from that feed Get content
Reading those N news sites contents
Summarizing the those contents with an AI model

Get News
In this level that is the first level of the software, The program request an RSS feed page to get all the news from that source. how we do that? programs uses a library called go-feed to get and parse the Feed Rss page for us (we also can get the page by ourselves first and then give it to the go-feed to parse them)
itâ€™s important to note that we get all page (the entire news) and then we sort and limit the amount that we want.
We can sort the page by any arbitrary property of that news object, for example we use the date of the articles/news.
with doing this we can get all the news from that source and choose to work with the one that we need
Get content
After that we got the RSS news item objects, there is multiple properties that we can use to get our desire news, like Title, Description, And the important one â€˜Linkâ€™, why is it so important because we use that link to read the content of that news object item.
for doing this software will make N concurrent green-threads and get those sites content, and after that we can use something called a reader-engine to read the page by some special algorithms and get the important content out of them.
What is RSS?
Date
RSS 0.90 released 1999 - 26 years ago
what is it
ØªØ´Ú©ÛŒÙ„ Ø´Ø¯Ù‡ Ø§Ø² really simple syndication ÛŒØ§ Rich site summary Ø§Ø³Øª Ú©Ù‡ Ø¨Ø±Ø§ÛŒ Ø¨Ø¯Ø³Øª Ø§ÙˆØ±Ø¯Ù† Ø§Ø®Ø±ÛŒÙ† Ø§Ø®Ø¨Ø§Ø± ÛŒØ§ Ø§Ø·Ù„Ø§Ø¹Ø§Øª Ø§Ø² ÛŒÚ© ÙˆØ¨Ø³Ø§ÛŒØª Ø¨Ù‡ ØµÙˆØ±Øª Ø§Ø³ØªØ§Ù†Ø¯Ø§Ø±Ø¯ Ù…ÙˆØ±Ø¯ Ø§Ø³ØªÙØ§Ø¯Ù‡ Ù‚Ø±Ø§Ø± Ù…ÛŒÚ¯ÛŒØ±Ø¯.
Often summarize the contents
Often, when websites provide web feeds to notify users of content updates, they only include summaries in the web feed rather than the full content itself. Many news websites, weblogs, schools and podcasters operate web feeds. As web feeds are designed to be machine-readable rather than human-readable they can also be used to automatically transfer information from one website to another without any human intervention.
Number of items in RSS
Although the number of items in an RSS channel is theoretically unlimited, some news aggregators do not support RSS files larger than 150KB.
How got famous
Although RSS formats have evolved from as early as March 1999,[6] it was between 2005 and 2006 when RSS gained widespread use, and the ("") icon was decided upon by several major web browsers.[7] RSS feed data is presented to users using software called a news aggregator and the passing of content is called web syndication. Users subscribe to feeds either by entering a feedâ€™s URI into the reader or by clicking on the browserâ€™s feed icon. The RSS reader checks the userâ€™s feeds regularly for new information and can automatically download it, if that function is enabled.
What is Reader engine?
Chrome reader mode engine DomDistiller
kholase: It does work by reading the DOM and then scoring each element, it work better for some special elements like P or DIV or Article.
You need at least one  tag around the text, that you want to see in Reader View, and at least 516 characters in 7 words inside the text.
for example this will trigger the ReaderView:

- medium.com/@tahirbalarabe2/what-is-ollama-running-large-language-models-locally-e917ca40defe
What is Ollama?
Ollama is an advanced AI platform that brings large language models directly to your device. With its privacy-first approach and high-speed processing, Ollama enables seamless AI interactions without cloud dependencies. Whether youâ€™re coding, automating tasks, or engaging in deep conversations, Ollama provides a reliable and customizable AI experience.
Optimization of models
One of the standout features of Ollama is its use of quantization to optimize model performance. Quantization reduces the computational load, allowing these models to run efficiently on consumer-grade laptops and desktops. This is no small feat, considering the size and complexity of modern LLMs. It also means you can use AI offline, keeping your data on your device for enhanced security and privacy.
Customizing the models
Customization is another area where Ollama shines. It uses something called a â€œmodel file,â€ which is essentially a text file that defines how a model should be built, customized, and configured. In this file, you can specify a base model, set default system prompts, and even fine-tune the model using a method called LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation). LoRA is a lightweight fine-tuning technique that adapts pre-trained models to specific tasks without altering the original weights. This makes it possible to specialize models for niche applications without the need for full retraining, which can be resource-intensive.
Authors
Itâ€™s a Canadian company that made this tool
Models
llama3.1
Itâ€™s a great ai LLM model made by meta
phi3
Developed by Microsoft.

Trained data
Our training data includes a wide variety of sources, totaling 3.3 trillion tokens, and is a combination of 1) publicly available documents filtered rigorously for quality, selected high-quality educational data, and code; 2) newly created synthetic, â€œtextbook-likeâ€ data for the purpose of teaching math, coding, common sense reasoning, general knowledge of the world (science, daily activities, theory of mind, etc.); 3) high quality chat format supervised data covering various topics to reflect human preferences on different aspects such as instruct-following, truthfulness, honesty and helpfulness.

06---Study/Semester-02/Operating-System-.title: Linux WC command
06---Study/Semester-02/Operating-System-.content:
What is â€˜WCâ€™ command?
Itâ€™s a simple command to return these 3 things:

print newline
print word
print byte counts

for each file.
Why use WC command?
Mostly we use wc commands to get these things:

to get line count of a file
to get byte count of a file
to get word count of a file
to get character count of a file

For Example
Get the lines of â€˜gameâ€™ file
$ wc game -l
30 game
Get the character counts of â€˜gameâ€™ file (notice character is the actual byte representation)
wc game -m
300 game
Get the word counts of â€˜gameâ€™ file (notice word only composed of actual Alphabet words)
wc game -w
150 game
Get the bytes counts of â€˜gameâ€™ file (notice bytes composed of anything inside the file)

06---Study/Semester-02/System-Programmin.title: Threading
06---Study/Semester-02/System-Programmin.content:
Class Concepts
Thread

Event system in threads
Single threaded os
cooperative multi thread system:

send yield: each software should return a yield command after its done


Preemptive Multitasking:

interrupts:

Intel Pentium made this built-in
Pentium 4 started a method called Hyper-threading. It means each processor can have 2 threads / logical cores.
os sends interrupts to programs (this method prevents crash for software)




Threading: each program can have its own thread
Logical Threads: virtual process:

each software thread can run only on 1 logical process


Thread pool
Registers (briefly)
Context Switching

Q&A
1: what is the maximum number of threads for one core:
refs:
stack-Change
This is what you want to know
Thread(s) per core:    2
Core(s) per socket:    12
Socket(s):             4

You have 4 CPU sockets, each CPU can have, up to, 12 cores and each core can have two threads.
Your max thread count is, 4 CPU x 12 cores x 2 threads per core, so 12 x 4 x 2 is 96. Therefore the max thread count is 96 and max core count is 48.
What is better ?
That depends on what you want to do, more threads means less frequency (ie a 3ghz becomes split in two) but better multi-tasking (more threads) and using full cores (no hyper-threading) is better for high CPU usage tasks (ie games).
Hope this helps you.
2. Does threads share the same memory?
Threads share the same memory space. Each process has its own set of system resources. Threads share resources within the same process. Processes are more independent of each other.
Exam (Ø¯Ø± Ø§Ù…ØªØ­Ø§Ù† Ù…ÛŒØ§Ø¯)
ØªÙØ§ÙˆØª process Ùˆ thread (Ù†Ø®)
Refs:

Preemptive and cooperative multi tasking
HyperThreading
Thread Word File
A Good video about threading in python youtube (Threading in Python)
ChatGPT chats about threading - chatGPT


Exercise Concepts
What is thread actually
Threads are the concepts that we use in computer science to give tasks to units of CPU that are IDLE and donâ€™t have something to work on. That means if a part of the CPU is waiting for the result of another part of it, we can give that idle part a job of other tasks to perform, this way we can fill the gap of being idle by waiting for something else.
As cores are actual physical things, threads are just software. With that said, when we say this CPU supports N threads, it doesnâ€™t mean CPU itself has real threads, but that the CPU supports simultaneous multi threading (hyper threading) meaning that when a core is in the middle of processing an instruction that results in having to wait for a slower operation to complete, that core can begin executing some instructions from another thread for a while.
Then:
Hyper-threading is a technology that allows each core in a CPU to work on multiple tasks at once by simulating additional virtual cores. This can improve performance in certain applications that benefit from parallel processing.
Then:
On the software side we have another similar concept also called â€˜threadsâ€™, which is just multiple separate processes operating under a single process. The main process manages data between the threads. Each thread can only be run under a single core or single logical core, so a process creating many software threads is a way it can operate on multiple logical cores simultaneously.
Threading in Python

Each process have 1 main thread, and you can call more other threads with that main thread.

we can use .start() to start a thread, and .join() to wait until the thread finish its job
For sharing data between threads we can use global scope variables, but we should be careful because if multiple thread access 1 shared object then weâ€™ll have â€˜Race Conditionâ€™. Then we need to â€˜lockâ€™ the state of the global shared variable for each thread callback.
We can do it with threading.Lock() and aquire() and release() functions.
we can make a queue of job with a simple array and lock to prevent all those things that said above
we can return values by using the extend Threading class or same global variables.
Another way to communicate with the threads is to use Events. Event class is a simple class where we can set a value (boolean) for an event and then we can access it on our thread to check the event and do functionalities based on that.

Provider/Consumer architecture model
for doing this, we need to make 2 threads and 1 queue that shares between threads
after that, we can put data by provider and get data by consumer and stop them when provider put a None value in queue. the queue needs to be compatible with threads

How does threading and multi processing work
Threads and Multi-Threading
we have 2 different kind of threads:

User threads: support on top of kernel, and manages without kernel support
Kernel threads: Supported and managed directly by the operating system

And for connecting those threads there are different ways, at usual we have 3 ways to relate user threads with kernel threads:

Many-to-one: Many user thread to 1 kernel thread
one-to-one: One user thread to one kernel thread
One user thread map to 1 kernel thread
Many-to-many: Many user thread to many kernel threads

Itâ€™s very important that kernel threads are not actually easy to make and thatâ€™s why we have some runtime solutions like user space threads (Gorouting) that map to each OS (kernel) thread and do concurrency.
Hyper-threading and Process Cores
Usually we have 1 CPU and some cores, for example if your CPU has 4 cores then you have a quad core CPU, this means you have 4 Physical Core that your hardware handle them.
And for sure, you can run multi-threaded programs on each core, and have multi processing system.
But what about Hyper-Threading ? Hyper-Threading means we have 2 more logical/virtual cores per 1 physical/actual core. That means if we have 4 physical cores, we actually have 8 logical cores from hyper-threading. With this way, we can do more jobs (partial 2x) but not actual real parallelism.
Why not real parallelism? because are using only Logical Cores and not physical cores and Logical cores shares the hardware of physical cores, For example:
Physical Core â€˜Aâ€™:
Logical Core â€˜AL0â€™
Logical Core â€˜AL1â€™
Logical Core â€˜AL0â€™ and â€˜AL1â€™ shares the hardware components of Physical core â€˜Aâ€™. This means we donâ€™t have actual parallelism, but it can runs faster and smoother.
And now we can run multi-threaded programs on each logical/virtual cores and get partial parallelism. but for real parallelism, we need to actually use physical cores.
Now you may say, Ok, then how to use physical cores? The answer is you cannot. but you can trick the OS to do that. We canâ€™t directly talk to physical cores because hardware doesnâ€™t have any API for that, that means operating system doesnâ€™t know how much physical cores do we have, it just knows about logical cores and act like we have that much of real cores. if you have 6 physical cores, and hyper-threading enabled, then OS will work on 12 cores (logical cores) cause OS can only talk to logical cores at hardware level. with that said, if we want to have the real parallelism, we need to tell the operating system to put each thread on different logical core, and because we only have 2 logical cores, this will trigger the hardware to change the physical cores for us. That is what libraries like OpenMP does at the High level for the user/developer.

07---Tech/00---Back-end-Programming/Conc.title: Clean Architecture
07---Tech/00---Back-end-Programming/Conc.content:
Clean Architecture book

There are some principles that we can use to have a clean architecture project:

Separation of concerns: Each level in your program should be separated by clear barrier, the transport layer, the service layer, the storage layerâ€¦
Dependencies inversion Principles (DIP): Yourâ€™s injecting the dependencies in your layer. You donâ€™t directly call them. Why? it promotes loose coupling and makes it easier to test your program.
Adaptability to Change: By organizing your code in a module and flexible way, you can more easily introduce more features, refactor existing code, and response to evolving business requirements.
Focus on business values: and finally, focus on delivering value to your users, they are the ones who will paying your bills at the end of the month. So focus on the business value.

With all that said, we can separate our software to these layers (SOC):

Transport: the way that we deliver message to our users, like HTTP or Grpc
Service: business logic lives (optional)
Storage: abstracts the communication above and below, which is database or any type of storage


Injection dependencies focus on abstraction not implementation (interface > struct)

for example we can inject a mock service or database to test the program without using any real code bases.
we should make our application configurable and at runtime regardless where itâ€™s deployed.
Things I found interesting

saga pattern: itâ€™s like we make a revert transaction system for a component

07---Tech/00---Back-end-Programming/Conc.title: DNS
07---Tech/00---Back-end-Programming/Conc.content:
DNS (Domain Name System): The Internetâ€™s Phonebook
DNS is a hierarchical, distributed naming system that translates human-readable domain names (like example.com) into numerical IP addresses (like 93.184.216.34) that computers use to identify each other on the network.

Purpose: Eliminates the need for users to remember complex IP addresses.
Hierarchical Structure:

Root Servers: The top of the hierarchy, knows where to find Top-Level Domain (TLD) servers.
TLD Servers: Manage domains like .com, .org, .net, .io. They know which authoritative name servers are responsible for specific domains.
Authoritative Name Servers: Hold the actual DNS records for a domain (e.g., example.com) and are the final authority for those names.


DNS Resolution Process:

User types example.com.
Local DNS resolver (often provided by ISP) receives the query.
Resolver queries a root server, which points to the .com TLD server.
Resolver queries the .com TLD server, which points to example.comâ€™s authoritative name server.
Resolver queries the authoritative name server, which returns the IP address for example.com.
The IP address is returned to the userâ€™s browser, which then connects to that IP.


Caching: DNS queries are heavily cached at various levels (browser, OS, local resolver) to speed up subsequent lookups.
Record Types:

A (Address): Maps a domain name to an IPv4 address.
AAAA (Quad-A): Maps a domain name to an IPv6 address.
CNAME (Canonical Name): Creates an alias from one domain name to another.
MX (Mail Exchange): Specifies mail servers responsible for accepting email for a domain.
NS (Name Server): Specifies the authoritative name servers for a domain.
TXT (Text): Holds arbitrary text, often used for verification or SPF records.
SRV (Service): Specifies hostname and port for specific services.


Importance for Backend:

Service Discovery: Backend microservices often use internal DNS records to find each other.
Load Balancing: DNS Round Robin (distributing traffic by returning different IP addresses for the same domain) is a basic form of load balancing.
CDN Integration: CDNs use DNS to direct users to the nearest edge location.

07---Tech/00---Back-end-Programming/Conc.title: HTTP
07---Tech/00---Back-end-Programming/Conc.content:
Stateless
the server is stateless, it means client for each actions - each time needs to request to the web server
benefits

Simplcity
scalability

because that HTTP is stateless, then developers often imlements state managment technichs such as:

coockies
session
tokens
for things like user logins, or shoping, etc.

Itâ€™s very important that client always initial the request.
Before sending anything, client and server needs to make a connection, they will provide it with TCP (Transfer Layer Protocol) that will initial the connection between 2 devices.
HTTP Versions
HTTP 1.0
Each request open a new connection
HTTP 1.1
Enable multiple request and response over the same connectino
Caching
HTTP 2.0
Multiplxing: multiple request or responses over a single connection
header compression
server push: server send resouces before client sends them
HTTP 3.0
Quick Protocol: transport layer over UDP, instead of TCP
Imporoved performance, reduce latency and packet lost
multiplexing without headofline blocking (still an issue in HTTP 2.0)
HTTP Request/Response/Header Structure
Request
PUT /api/users/12345 HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com
User-Agnet: Mozzila/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64)
...
 
// a blank line here means, everything has been sent
 
{
	"firstName": "John",
	"lastName": "Wing",
	"email": "wing@gmail.com",
	"age": 30
}
Response
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Date: Fri, 20 Sep 2024 12:00:00 GMT
Content-Type: application/json
....
 
// a blank line here means, everything has been sent
 
{
	"message": "User updated succsessfully",
	"userId": 12345,
	"status": "success"
}
Headers
Headers are key-value pair of different perramiter, but why we use beaders?:
Headers are actual meta data values that we send to server or recieve from server to make a proper connection. Also headers have more use cases.
example of useful header keys/values:
Request headers

User-Agent: identifies what kind of client is that
Authorization: to identifies the user (use cases like tokens)
Accept: which provide information what kind of content we are expect

General headers
we use this type of header both in req and resp

Date: date of the message
Cache-Control: Caching mechanism
Connection: connection information like keep it alive or close it.

Representation headers
Usually specifies the way to represent the data

Content-Type: the actual type of content (json, image, HTML)
Content-Length: The length of the whole size of the resouce packet in bytes
Content-Encoding: which kind of encoding does data has (like gzip, diffler)
ETag: unique Identify which mostly uses per cache

Security Headers
Enhance the security of request/response by controlling the behavior of caching and, etc.

Strick-Transport-Security (HSTS): Insuring that client only communicate with server, or https preventing protocol downgrade.
Content-Security-Policy (CSP): strict which content like js,image,html can be loaded
X-Frame-Options: Prevents the page to be embedded in iframe
X-Content-Type-Options: Prevent the browser to quess the mimetype
Set-Cookie: Secure cookies that are accesiable to javascript, and ensuring they are sending over the HTTPS

Headers can be used in more ares because of:

Extensibility: when we use headers, we can use/add features without modifies the underlying HTTP/HTTP protocol, some of them can even be custom that made by other devs (X-* headers)
Remove Control: We can use header to actually control the behavior of server by providing some options inside the header, for example we can authenticate the user or server can set a cache mechanism to cache the data for client browser, or we can set our own custom header for more extensible functions.

HTTP Methods
Http method are exists to represent different kinds of actions by client, like browser or api consumer. For example If we want to get the name of the user, we can set the Intent of our request, then we can functions differently than for example modify it.
Http methods are:

GET: we use it to get some resources from the server
POST: We use it to put some resources to the server, it has the body to set data from the client
PUT: Update some resources from the server but it should replace whatever we provide as body to the target resource (Complete Replacement)
PATCH: Update some resources from the server but it should only patch (modify) the part of the resource that we provided as body (Modify only needed parts)
DELETE: We use to delete a resource from the server.
OPTIONS (CORS): it used to fetch the capability of the server for Cross Origin Requests (CORS), it controls how browser should communicate the the server resources from different host addresses.

Note that Host is used for the target api that we want to request.
And we use Origin is used for our own local domain (or maybe a domain from a server).
Idempotent or non-idempotent
Please See The Idempotency section.
Response Code
they will return the final state or situation of functioned request from the server as a code, this code perfectly specifies what was the exact result of the request.
This code is standard and works across all platform, languages, systems, etc.
On High level response codes composed from:

Information:  1xx
Success:      2xx
Redirection:  3xx
Client Error: 4xx
Server Error: 5xx

for example 200 is OK message that means request was succsessful and completed properly by the server.
Or 201 means resource has been fulfill in the reason of Creation a resource (F.g POST Method)
or 204 means request has been fulfill in the reason of accepting content, but there is nothing to return by the server itself (Nothing to return).
301 means move permanently, that means the requested resource has been moved to a new URL, and request should be in that new URL. (F.g backwards compatibility)
302 means move temporarly, that means the request resource has been temporarely moves to a new URL, but the future request will continue uses the main URL. (F.g for testing things or running temp events like campains)
304 means the resource has not been modified since the last request (F.g GET Method, Caching)
400 means bad request, we use to when the data from client is not correct and server needs a better format of data.
401 means Unauthorized, we use this to say you are not authorized or failed at that level (F.g server is using JWT, but client didnâ€™t provide that or it is expired)
403 means Forbidden, we use this when the client tried to access a resource but they donâ€™t have the permission for that (like when we are filtered from other sites xd)
404 means Resource not Found, we use this when client wants some resources that are not available in the server.
405 means Method is not allowed, we use this to give information to client that this method is not allowed for this server or for example for this route.
409 means conflict, we use this for miltiple reason, but for example we can return this code when use wants to add an resource that is already available to the server, and server can say that there is some conflict with available resource here.
429 means too many request, we use this to allow limited amount of requests and if they are succeeds out of that, we return this code (F.g Rate limit systems)
500 means internal server error, we use this to give information about some internal server errors, this is not related to clients and itâ€™s only for internal components of the server. (F.g Something unexpected happend)
501 means not implemented, we use this when the server doesnâ€™t support the HTTP method or any functionality, but it plants to implement it soon.
502 means bad gateway, Usually proxy server use this, they use it to say upstream proxy server returns an invalid response.
503 means service is not available
504 means gateway timeout, for example when we request to a server that uses reverse proxy in front and that reverse proxy cannot access the internal local server (Main web server), after some time (timeout) that reverse proxy can return this code.
Caching
We use this mechanism to recognize the re-use of the resource and cache them then, we can more quckily access the resource.
we usually control cache with HTTP headers, such as:
Cache-Control header
means: you should maintain the cache for this resource for N seconds
Cache-Control: max-age=30, public

In this example, client should maintain the cache for 30 seconds.
ETag header
they are usually hashes of the response message
Etag: 3141

Last-Modified Header
with this header method, we can see what was the last time that resource modifies
Last-Modified: Fri, 28 Sep 2024 13:48:33 GMT

what Usually happens here is that server will send those 3 headers that we talked about to the server, then the next time client request the resources, client will provide those header values with a new key names such as:

If-None-Mache (same as Etag)
If-Modified-Since (Same as Last-Modified)

To the server, and then server will check those with its own values of those headers, if they are same then return the 403 code (Not Modified) and if they are not same, then return the newly created resource to the client. itâ€™s also noticeable that server will add another header called Cache-Control that we talked about, that means please do the new request after this N seconds, until that cache the current data.
Benefits

load time
reduces bandwidth
gain speed

Refrences:

www.youtube.com/watch

07---Tech/00---Back-end-Programming/Conc.title: Idempotency
07---Tech/00---Back-end-Programming/Conc.content:
Idempotency
An operation is idempotent if applying it multiple times produces the same result as applying it once. For network requests, especially in distributed systems, idempotency is crucial because requests can be retried due to network glitches or timeouts.

Example: A POST request to create a new resource is typically not idempotent (sending it twice might create two resources). A PUT request to update a resource is idempotent (sending it multiple times has the same final state).
Backend Best Practice: Design your API endpoints to be idempotent where possible, especially for operations that modify data. If not inherently idempotent, implement mechanisms (e.g., unique transaction IDs) to ensure repeated requests donâ€™t cause unintended side effects.

07---Tech/00---Back-end-Programming/Conc.title: Load Balancers
07---Tech/00---Back-end-Programming/Conc.content:
Load Balancers: Distributing the Workload
Load balancers distribute incoming network traffic across a group of backend servers (a server farm or pool). This ensures high availability, scalability, and improved performance.

Why Needed:

Scalability: Allows adding more backend servers to handle increased traffic.
High Availability: If one server fails, traffic is redirected to healthy servers.
Performance: Prevents a single server from becoming a bottleneck.


Types:

Layer 4 Load Balancers (TCP/UDP): Operate at the transport layer, forwarding traffic based on IP address and port number. Fast and efficient.
Layer 7 Load Balancers (HTTP/HTTPS): Operate at the application layer, understanding HTTP/HTTPS protocols. Can make more intelligent routing decisions based on URL paths, HTTP headers, cookies, etc. Often perform SSL/TLS termination.


Algorithms:

Round Robin: Distributes requests sequentially to each server.
Least Connections: Sends requests to the server with the fewest active connections.
IP Hash: Directs client requests to the same server based on a hash of the clientâ€™s IP address (useful for session stickiness without cookies).


Health Checks: Load balancers continuously monitor the health of backend servers and automatically remove unhealthy ones from the pool, redirecting traffic to healthy servers.
Backend Impact: When designing backend services, assume they will be behind a load balancer. Services should be stateless or handle session persistence externally.

07---Tech/00---Back-end-Programming/Conc.filePath: 07 - Tech/00 - Back-end Programming/Concepts/Repository pattern vs Data Access Layer.md
07---Tech/00---Back-end-Programming/Conc.title: Repository pattern vs Data Access Layer
07---Tech/00---Back-end-Programming/Conc.content:
As we process to focus on domains (F.g User, Game, Shows) in RP and make codes based on that, we try to make a very general and dynamic system for DAL (data access layer). This means that in DAL, we only make the abstraction layer itself and doesnâ€™t work with any meaning or entities, just pure functionality of that subject (mostly database). A great example is GORM, this lib doesnâ€™t have any relation with the types and tables that we are going to make, but it gives us the functionality to work with them (implementations not just domains and subjects).
But in RP, we care about the domain specefic implementation (F.g GetUser, GetEmailByName, GetScore). and this can shows us a very important quote:

Data Access Layer is working underneth the Repository Pattern, what I mean by that is we use DAL inside the RP. We make all functionalities of database and then we use it domain based on RP functions (getUset).

 
type UserRepository struct {
    db *gorm.DB
}
 
func (r *UserRepository) GetByEmail(email string) (*User, error) {
    var u User
    err := r.db.Where("email = ?", email).First(&u).Error
    return &u, err
}
 
func (r *UserRepository) Save(u *User) error {
    return r.db.Save(u).Error
}
 
AI Good Quotes
Repository Pattern is a higher-level abstraction


It works with domain concepts (User, Order, Product)


It hides the DAL from business logic


It contains domain-specific queries


It returns domain models instead of rows


It is specific: one repository per aggregate/entity


Think of Repository as: â€œHow do I retrieve or persist domain objects?â€
How they work together (perfect combo)
ğŸ”½ Low-level
DAL / GORM / SQLX / pgx / raw SQL
Handles database logic.
ğŸ”¼ High-level
Repository Layer
Uses DAL to fetch/update domain models.
ğŸ”¼ Higher-level
Service Layer (business logic)
Uses repositories to execute business rules.
ğŸ”¼ Top-level
Handlers / Controllers (HTTP)
Call services.

07---Tech/02---Game-Programming/Godot/Go.title: Godot 3D Doc notes
07---Tech/02---Game-Programming/Godot/Go.content:
General

To find a vector pointing from A to B, use B - A.

Scalar

Vectors represent both direction and magnitude (length). A value representing only magnitude is called a scalar. Scalars use the float type in Godot.

Unit vectors
A vector with magnitude of 1 is called a unit vector. They are also sometimes referred to as direction vectors or normals. Unit vectors are helpful when you need to keep track of a direction.
Normalization
Normalizing a vector means reducing its length to 1 while preserving its direction. This is done by dividing each of its components by its magnitude. Because this is such a common operation, Godot provides a dedicated normalized() method for this:
Q&As
Read more about Dot Product and Cross Product.
Gilbert Strang lectures on Linear Algebra (MIT) for better understanding of linear algebra.

07---Tech/04---Go/Concepts/Refrences.title: Refrences
07---Tech/04---Go/Concepts/Refrences.content:
In Go, a weak pointer refers to a reference that does not prevent the garbage collector (GC) from reclaiming the target object.
When an object is only referenced by weak pointers and has no strong references, the GC will still treat it as unreachable and reclaim it; afterwards, all weak pointers to it will automatically become nil.
In short, a weak pointer does not increase an objectâ€™s reference count. When an object is referenced only by weak pointers, the garbage collector can free it. Therefore, before attempting to use the value of a weak pointer, you should check whether it is nil.

07---Tech/07---Concepts/How-USB-Works.title: How USB Works
07---Tech/07---Concepts/How-USB-Works.content:
USB is a serial port.
Other serial ports at not hotplug or auto configable.
All USB variants with their speed:

USB 1.0 [lowSpeed: 1.5Mbs, maxSpeed: 12Mbs]
USB 2.0 [maxSpeed: 480Mbs]
USB 3.0 [maxSpeed: 5Gbs]
USB 3.1 [maxSpeed: 10Gbs]

Because USB is asynchronous, then there is not any clock line
USB is hard in the case of implementations than UART
USB has to kind of connections connectors:

USB A: for host machines like computer (up-stream)
USB B: for client machines like indivisual devices (down-stream)

For sending data a USB uses 2 data lines called (D+, D-), usb uses D+ for Full-speed supported computers and low D- for low-speed supported computers.
USB can send 4 different type of data (4 data transition types for USB):

Control: exchange all the settings and configurations between USB and host
Isochronous: For time critical devices like speakers, that has real-time communication with no error detection
Bulk: devices like printers that accept one big block of data instead of serializing the data (!= Isochronous)
